Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned that reading with 現れる, but here's a mnemonic to help you:

The monster under your bed decides <vocabulary>to show</vocabulary> you its true form. "You… <reading>are a wa</reading>lrus (あらわ)?" you ask, shocked. Evidently, the monster under your bed was actually just a walrus who got in one day when you left the window open. You feel silly for being scared of it for so long, but you're glad it finally showed itself to you.

examples.en: There is a park with a beautiful view near my house.
examples.ja: 家の近くに景色の良い公園があります。

examples.en: I love this landscape we can see from here.
examples.ja: ここから見る景色が大好きなんです。

examples.en: Do you want to take a detour today to see some different scenery than usual?
examples.ja: ちょっといつもと違った景色を見るために、今日は回り道をしてみない？

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>scene</kanji>'s <kanji>color</kanji> is the <vocabulary>scenery</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>landscape</vocabulary>, and <vocabulary>view</vocabulary>. Looking good, scenery!
reading_mnemonic:
You haven't learned either of these readings yet. Here's a mnemonic to help you remember them:

You're admiring the <vocabulary>scenery</vocabulary> and you notice key marks all over everything. You realize it's that girl who keys everything and you say to yourself <reading>kay she key</reading>ed (けしき) that, <reading>kay she key</reading>ed (けしき) this.

examples.en: Do you think ghosts really exist?
examples.ja: お化けって本当に居ると思いますか？

examples.en: Wait, that celebrity is still around? I wonder how old she is now.
examples.ja: え？あの芸能人ってまだ居たの？今何才なんだろう？

examples.en: Our cat is usually in our bedroom upstairs.
examples.ja: うちの猫は大抵二階の寝室に居るんです。

meaning_mnemonic:
Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>alive</kanji> and the verb version means <vocabulary>to exist</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to be</vocabulary>, for anything that is alive and moving, like people and animals. 

The kanji isn't used too often for this word, so when you're writing just use the kana. But you'll see the kanji used sometimes so it's important to be able to recognize it!
reading_mnemonic: Do you know the word いる? This is the kanji version! If you've been studying Japanese up to this point you probably already know that word. You can associate these two things together into one and remember the reading at the same time!

examples.en: I've ordered new business cards.
examples.ja: 新しい名刺を注文しました。

examples.en: Come to think of it, we need to make business cards for the new hires, don't we?
examples.ja: そういえば、新人の名刺を作る必要がありますね。

examples.en: I received a business card from the president of that company.
examples.ja: あの会社の社長さんから名刺をもらいました。

meaning_mnemonic: Take your <kanji>name</kanji> and <kanji>stab</kanji> someone with it... using your <vocabulary>business card</vocabulary>. Your business card has your name on it. Also, you "stab" it at people who are willing to take it and read it. Not a real stab, but a metaphorical.
reading_mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. You haven't learned this reading for 刺 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

After doing business in Japan, you'll have so many <vocabulary>business card</vocabulary>s you can count them like <reading>shee</reading>p (し) when you're trying to get to sleep. One business card, two business cards… See them leaping over the sheep fence as you begin to nod off.

examples.en: Your pay will be deposited in the bank on the fifth day of every month.
examples.ja: 給料は毎月五日に銀行に振りこまれます。

examples.en: You're not doing your job at all. You salary thief!
examples.ja: お前、全然仕事できてねーじゃん。この給料どろぼう！

examples.en: With only my salary, we’re in the red if we continue with our current lifestyle.
examples.ja: 私の給料だけだと、今の生活スタイルのままじゃ赤字なんだよね。

examples.en: "I heard your boss is going to give you a raise." "Really? That’ll be the day."
examples.ja: 「君の上司が、君の給料を上げるつもりだって聞いたよ。」「まさか！そんなことあり得ないよ。」

meaning_mnemonic: Your <kanji>salary</kanji> <kanji>fee</kanji> are the moneys you get for your <vocabulary>salary</vocabulary>. These are your <vocabulary>wages</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>pay</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: What was the reason for the pay cut?
examples.ja: 減給の原因は何だったんですか？

examples.en: Isn't this essentially a pay cut?
examples.ja: これって、実質的には減給じゃないですか？

examples.en: I never expected a pay cut, so I stayed at a first-rate hotel to round off my journey.
examples.ja: まさか減給があるなんて思いもしなかったから、旅の締めくくりに一流ホテルにとまっちゃったんだよね。

examples.en: I got a pay cut and my boss is mean so I’m seriously thinking of quitting and looking for a different job.
examples.ja: 減給されるし、上司も嫌なヤツだし、会社を辞めて転職先をさがすことを本気で考えてるんだよね。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>decrease</kanji> in <kanji>salary</kanji> is a <vocabulary>pay cut</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: I will definitely achieve WaniKani Level 60!
examples.ja: 絶対にワニカニレベル６０を達成してみせる！

examples.en: No way, that's absolutely impossible.
examples.ja: いやいや、絶対無理でしょ。

examples.en: That's not true! You can definitely do it, I believe in you!
examples.ja: そんなことないよ、君なら絶対大丈夫だよ！

examples.en: You can’t go out on a school night. If I say it’s no good, it’s absolutely no good!
examples.ja: 学校のある夜は、外出できないって言ってるでしょ。ダメだと言ったら絶対にダメだからね！

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Extinction</kanji> will happen as you go <kanji>versus</kanji> extinction. It will happen <vocabulary>absolutely</vocabulary>. It will happen <vocabulary>without fail</vocabulary>. There's nothing you can do to stop extinction.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Be careful though, 絶 is normally read as ぜつ, but in this case it is shortened to ぜっ.

examples.en: I am a hopelessly bad singer.
examples.ja: 私は絶望的に歌が下手です。

examples.en: When my teacher told me that, I was filled with despair.
examples.ja: 先生にそう言われたとき、絶望感でいっぱいになりました。

examples.en: Now, having been dumped by my boyfriend, I’m in the depths of despair.
examples.ja: 今、彼氏にフラレて、絶望のどん底にいる。

examples.en: The other team is fifteen goals ahead of us, so we are in a pretty hopeless situation.
examples.ja: 相手チームに15点差で負けているので、かなり絶望的な状況です。

meaning_mnemonic: When <kanji>hope</kanji> has <kanji>died out</kanji>, you have no more hope, only <vocabulary>despair</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: It's a bit late for you to tell me that now.
examples.ja: 今更そんなことを言われても困るよ。

examples.en: I can't ask my teacher about such basic things now.
examples.ja: こんな基本中の基本のこと、先生には今更聞けないよ。

examples.en: After all this time, I've just realized that Windows 7 finally stopped receiving official support.
examples.ja: 今更ながら、Windows 7のサポートが終了していることに気づきました。

examples.en: It may be a little late, but I started carrying around my own pair of chopsticks.
examples.ja: 今更ですが、マイ箸を持ち歩き始めました。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Now</kanji> isn’t good enough for <kanji>renew</kanji>al. It’s already <vocabulary>too late</vocabulary>. The time has passed <vocabulary>now</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: You might be tempted to read this with on’yomi, but this is actually 今 and 更に put together, just without the に particle at the end. Try to remember it in this way, or just make a mental note to use kun’yomi here!

examples.en: It is almost time to change out the clothes for the season.
examples.ja: そろそろ衣がえの季節です。

examples.en: Can you tell me how to make tempura batter?
examples.ja: 天ぷらの衣の作り方を教えてください。

examples.en: That doctor at the hospital is famous for speaking their mind without holding back.
examples.ja: あの病院の先生は、歯に衣着せぬ物の言い方をすることで有名です。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. In modern Japanese, 衣 is more often used to describe the clothes your food is wearing, e.g., the coating on tempura or the breading on deep-fried foods.
reading_mnemonic:
What are clothes, really? Some people say <vocabulary>clothes</vocabulary> are the <reading>chromo</reading>somes (ころも) of your personal style — each garment carries information about your unique identity. Other people say clothes are simply the <reading>key</reading> to not being <reading>nu</reading>de (きぬ). What do you think?

Both ころも and きぬ mean "clothes," but these usages are old-fashioned. Also note that the more modern meaning of "coating" or "breading" uses only the ころも reading!

examples.en: It is very cool today, isn’t it?
examples.ja: 今日はとても涼しいですね。

examples.en: I like that dress. Looks breezy.
examples.ja: いいね、そのドレス。涼しそう。

examples.en: How can you say such a thing with an indifferent face?
examples.ja: 涼しい顔でよくそんなこと言えるね。

meaning_mnemonic:
This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of <kanji>cool</kanji>? It's <vocabulary>cool</vocabulary>.

涼しい is used to describe a comfortable level of coolness, particularly one that's pleasant and <vocabulary>refreshing</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic:
The reading is the kun'yomi reading, but that's the reading you learned with the kanji so you should be able to read this one too. If you need a refresher, here's a mnemonic to help you:

Looking for a place that's <vocabulary>cool</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>refreshing</vocabulary>? Go to the <reading>Sue Zoo</reading> (すず). Imagine swimming with Sue the penguin in the refreshing water of her pool. Feels good!

examples.en: When I cast my eye around, I saw that I was surrounded by many police investigators.
examples.ja: 辺りを見渡すと、たくさんの捜査員達に取り囲まれていた。

examples.en: It is necessary for a company president to have the ability to survey their entire company.
examples.ja: 会社の社長には会社全体を見渡せる能力が必要です。

examples.en: The sunflower field went on as far as the eye could see.
examples.ja: 見渡す限り、向日葵畑が続いていた。

meaning_mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb.  The kanji means <kanji>see</kanji> and <kanji>transit</kanji>, but the vocab isn't quite the same. You are going to transit your eyes over an area to take in what you see. So you're really going <vocabulary>to look out over</vocabulary> everything. This word is usually used when you're looking at landscapes or a really large area.
reading_mnemonic: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You've learned both of these readings by now so you should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Please try to maintain a disciplined and orderly lifestyle by following a regular pattern of going to bed and waking up early.
examples.ja: 早寝早起きの規則正しい生活を送るよう、心がけてください。

examples.en: My child has developed a more regular eating pattern since starting to go to daycare.
examples.ja: うちの子は、保育園に行き始めてから、規則正しい食事が取れるようになりました。

examples.en: The students lined up in a well regulated fashion and entered the classroom.
examples.ja: 学生たちは規則正しく並んで教室に入っていった。

meaning_mnemonic:
This is a combination of the words 規則 and 正しい, that you learned already. If you follow the rules in the correct order, everything will stay <vocabulary>regular</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>orderly</vocabulary>.

This word means that something follows a regular pattern or schedule. It’s commonly used to describe disciplined lifestyles, such as with regular sleep, exercise, and healthy eating habits, and implies that the regularity is desirable.
reading_mnemonic: This is a combination of the words 規則 and 正しい, which you learned already, so you should be able to read this word too.

examples.en: The tutor put up a white board against the wall.
examples.ja: 家庭教師は、ホワイトボードをかべに立て掛けた。

examples.en: I work part time as a private teacher.
examples.ja: 家庭教師のアルバイトをしています。

examples.en: In Japan, tutoring is one of the most popular part-time jobs for college students, due to its short hours.
examples.ja: 日本では拘束時間の短い家庭教師は大学生に人気のあるアルバイトの一つです。

meaning_mnemonic: This is a combination of the words 家庭 and 教師. A "teacher" who only teaches when you're with your "family" is known as a <vocabulary>tutor</vocabulary>. They don't teach you at school, they're a <vocabulary>private teacher</vocabulary> that comes to your home to help you learn.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: My work hours are irregular.
examples.ja: 私の仕事は時間が不規則です。

examples.en: It's not good to have irregular bedtimes.
examples.ja: 寝る時間が不規則なのは良くないよ。

examples.en: My health was ruined by my disorderly life.
examples.ja: 不規則な生活で体調を崩してしまった。

meaning_mnemonic: You know that 規則 means "rule" or "regulation." So a <kanji>not</kanji> "rule" or "regulation" is an <vocabulary>irregularity</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Could you help me take down my luggage?
examples.ja: 荷物を降ろすのを手伝ってくれ。

examples.en: I was dropped off in front of the station.
examples.ja: 駅の前で降ろしてもらった。

examples.en: Excuse me, please let me off at the next corner.
examples.ja: すみません、次の角で降ろしてください。

meaning_mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. You already learned that 降りる means "to get off." This is when you're helping something else descend down from something, not when you yourself are getting down. So it means <vocabulary>to take down</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to lower</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This word uses the kun'yomi reading, which you already learned. Go you!

examples.en: The reaction towards this article was huge.
examples.ja: この記事への反響はとても大きかった。

examples.en: Koichi's screaming voice reverberated inside the tunnel.
examples.ja: トンネルの中にコウイチのさけび声が反響しました。

examples.en: This room is designed to reduce echoes.
examples.ja: この部屋は反響音が抑えられるように設計してあるんです。

meaning_mnemonic: An <kanji>anti</kanji> <kanji>echo</kanji> is still an <vocabulary>echo</vocabulary>! It's just going back and forth with a normal echo. Together they get a weird <vocabulary>reverberation</vocabulary> going.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: What should I do to finish the fight?
examples.ja: 争いを収めるにはどうすればいいのだろう。

examples.en: Koichi scored a landslide victory at this election.
examples.ja: コウイチは今回の選挙で圧倒的に勝利を収めた。

examples.en: I stored the evidence regarding Viet's political crime in the file.
examples.ja: ビエトの政治犯罪に関する証拠をファイルに収めました。

meaning_mnemonic:
When you <kanji>obtain</kanji> something you need to keep it safe, so you decide <vocabulary>to store</vocabulary> it somewhere. Then you can always go back and look at the thing you managed <vocabulary>to achieve</vocabulary> or  <vocabulary>to score</vocabulary>, and no one can take it from you.

収める means "to store" with an emphasis on placing something in their proper location. This nuance extends to convey a sense of accomplishment, such as "achieving a favorable outcome.”
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading with 収まる, but here's a mnemonic to remind you just in case:

You need <vocabulary>to store</vocabulary> all of the <reading>o</reading>ld <reading>saw</reading>s (おさ). You were able <vocabulary>to finish</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>to achieve</vocabulary> everything you wanted with them, so it's time to put them away so they'll be safe.

examples.en: The rain caused the river's water level to increase.
examples.ja: 雨がふって川の水かさが増しました。

examples.en: These days, a rumor that Tofugu is growing a lot is going around in the Japanese language education industry.
examples.ja: 最近、日本語教育業界でトーフグの勢いが増したとウワサになっています。

examples.en: Sugar will make it much sweeter, you know.
examples.ja: 砂糖でさらに甘みが増しますよ。

meaning_mnemonic:
It's another verb with the kanji 増! This one means <vocabulary>to increase</vocabulary> too! But!

Just like 増える, this is when something is just increasing on its own. You can use this word to talk about an increase in number, quantity, or degree, but it’s more literary and less common than 増える, except when referring to an increase in degree.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You haven't learned this reading yet so here's a mnemonic to help you:

What <vocabulary>increase</vocabulary>s with time? Your love for your <reading>ma</reading>ma (ま)! Your love for her will grow and grow the older you get! I love you, mama!

examples.en: I had the tutor teach me multiplication today.
examples.ja: 今日は家庭教師に掛け算を教えてもらいました。

examples.en: I solved 100 multiplication problems today.
examples.ja: 今日は掛け算の問題を100問解いたよ。

examples.en: There’s a multiplication test in cram school tomorrow.
examples.ja: 明日、塾で掛け算のテストがあるんです。

meaning_mnemonic: If you try to <kanji>calculate</kanji> something, but instead you feel the urge to <kanji>hang</kanji> your teacher, you know you're doing <vocabulary>multiplication</vocabulary>. It's hard, guys. Like really hard. The hardest kind of math of them all. But you can do it! No one needs to get hanged. And don't hang your head in defeat either. Multiply those numbers like a boss! Hang the numbers instead!!
reading_mnemonic: This is the kun'yomi reading for 掛 and the on'yomi for 算. And the さん reading is rendaku'd into ざん. This is the same for all the math-ish words (addition, subtraction, multiplication, and division), so try to remember that, because you'll see it again!

examples.en: There are many excellent engineers in Japan who are recognized worldwide.
examples.ja: 日本には世界に通用する優れた技術者がたくさんいます。

examples.en: In what ways would you say that WaniKani surpasses other kanji learning materials?
examples.ja: ワニカニはどういう点で他の漢字学習教材より優れていると言えますか？

examples.en: Tofugu surpasses the other Japanese learning materials in terms of uniqueness.
examples.ja: トーフグはユニークさにおいて、他の日本語学習教材より優れています。

examples.en: This movie is an excellent work that beautifully elevates the theme of the original work.
examples.ja: この映画は、原作のテーマを見事に昇華した非常に優れた作品となっている。

meaning_mnemonic:
This is the verb version of the kanji <kanji>superior</kanji>, so it means <vocabulary>to surpass</vocabulary>. Someone who is superior is always going to surpass and <vocabulary>to excel</vocabulary> beyond others. That's what makes them so superior in the first place!

This is a formal word that is often used in writing or formal speech.
reading_mnemonic: If you want to surpass everyone, you have to be super good (すぐ) at stuff. Like, super good at everything. Not pretty good, not really good — super good. Only then can you surpass all the others.

examples.en: A glass filled halfway with water can be perceived as "half empty" or "half full," depending on the person.
examples.ja: コップの半分まで入れられた水は、人によって「半分しかない」とも「半分もある」とも捉えられます。

examples.en: It's hard to grasp what Japanese clients are really thinking.
examples.ja: 日本人のクライアントの本音を捉えるのは難しい。

examples.en: Immediately after the show started, the circus troupe captivated the audience's hearts.
examples.ja: そのサーカス団は、開演してすぐに観客の心を捉えた。

meaning_mnemonic:
This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>catch</kanji> so the verb version is <vocabulary>to catch</vocabulary>.

Try to remember the mnemonic from the kanji with this one, because this word isn't used for physically catching things, but for ideas or meanings that you are able <vocabulary>to grasp</vocabulary>, metaphorically speaking.
reading_mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading with the kanji, so you should be able to read it already!

examples.en: My younger brother was strangled by a sheep.
examples.ja: 弟は羊に首を絞められた。

examples.en: In retrospect, I was basically creating a situation where I was shooting myself in the foot.
examples.ja: 後から見れば、結局、自分で自分の首を絞めるようなシチュエーションを作ってたんだよね。

examples.en: I had the experience of killing, butchering, and eating a chicken by myself for the first time in my life.
examples.ja: 生まれて初めて自分で鶏を絞めて、捌いて、食べるという経験をしました。

examples.en: "Strangling someone with floss silk” is a metaphor for subtly and slowly criticizing or tormenting someone, without directly confronting or attacking them.
examples.ja: 「真綿で首を絞める」とは、直接対峙したり攻撃したりすることなく、遠まわしに誰かをじわじわと責めたり、痛めつけたりすることのたとえです。

meaning_mnemonic:
The kanji means <kanji>strangle</kanji> and this vocab is the verb version of that: <vocabulary>to strangle</vocabulary>. It’s usually used in the phrase 首を絞める, which also means “to strangle.” 

There is another word, 絞る which means "to wring out" that looks very similar. You know that this one is "to strangle" because it has める sticking out of it. Imagine that in the <reading>mail</reading> (める) you get a letter that says "I'm going <vocabulary>to strangle</vocabulary> you!" When you get this in the mail, you know it's about strangling.
reading_mnemonic: The thing that is threatening <vocabulary>to strangle</vocabulary> you is actually a <reading>shee</reading>p (し)! The sheep comes to your house and says, "here's the sheep mail!" and then tries to strangle you. It puts its hard feet on your neck though it's pretty ineffective.

examples.en: Have you ever seen a werewolf?
examples.ja: 人狼を見たことがありますか。

examples.en: The truth is, the teacher of this class is a werewolf.
examples.ja: 実は、このクラスの先生は人狼なんです。

examples.en: "Werewolf" is a party game in which you distinguish between friends and a liar through conversation.
examples.ja: 「人狼」ゲームは、味方かウソつきかを会話で見分けるパーティーゲームです。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>person</kanji> <kanji>wolf </kanji> is a <vocabulary>werewolf</vocabulary>. This word is less common than 狼男, but it's used more and more thanks to the card game of the same name!
reading_mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You haven't learned the on'yomi for 狼 (wolf) yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you remember that, as well as which on'yomi to use for 人:

There's a <vocabulary>werewolf</vocabulary> in front of you wearing  <reading>jean</reading>s and eating <reading>roe</reading> (じんろう). This is typical behavior for werewolves, as I'm sure you know.

examples.en: Road construction costs huge amounts of money.
examples.ja: 道路建設には莫大な費用がかかる。

examples.en: If this situation continues, the cost could be enormous.
examples.ja: このままでは、コストが莫大になる可能性があります。

examples.en: The crab statue is beautiful, but no one will be happy with the huge amount of funds spent on it.
examples.ja: カニの像は美しいが、莫大な資金が使われたことについてはだれも喜ばないだろう。

meaning_mnemonic:
Something that is <kanji>endless</kanji>ly <kanji>big</kanji> isn't just big, but <vocabulary>huge</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>enormous</vocabulary>.

This word is often used in contexts that involve money, but it can also be used for other things like time, energy, and data.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: The night illumination of Okayama Castle was so beautiful!
examples.ja: 岡山城のライトアップ、めっちゃきれいだったよ！

examples.en: On Sunday, I visited the renovated Okayama Castle.
examples.ja: 日曜日、リニューアルした岡山城に行ってきました。

examples.en: If the weather is good, Okayama Castle will be clearly visible from here.
examples.ja: 天気が良ければ、ここからも岡山城がはっきり見えるんですよ。

meaning_mnemonic: This is the same 岡山 that you learned with 岡山県. So what's Okayama <kanji>castle</kanji>? Yep, <vocabulary>Okayama Castle</vocabulary>!
reading_mnemonic:
When 城 is added to a place name like this, it takes the on'yomi. You haven't learned this yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

The lord of <vocabulary>Okayama Castle</vocabulary> is none other than <reading>Joe</reading> (じょう), your local farmhand friend. How a farmhand like Joe managed to become the lord of a Japanese castle is beyond even us, but it's Lord Joe to you now.

examples.en: I'll add five more Amazon gift cards to the giveaway for every 100 retweets I get!
examples.ja: 100RT毎にプレゼントのアマギフを5枚追加するよ！

examples.en: Right now I'm giving him formula roughly every three hours.
examples.ja: 今は大体三時間毎にミルクをあげてる。

examples.en: We have our car inspected once every year.
examples.ja: うちの車は、一年毎に点検に出しています。

meaning_mnemonic:
Add a に to <kanji>every</kanji> and you get <vocabulary>for every</vocabulary>. This means something happens <vocabulary>at intervals of</vocabulary> a certain time frame or milestone, like <vocabulary>once every</vocabulary> year, month, day, etc.!

Note that this is very frequently written in hiragana, but you'll encounter the kanji version as well, especially when it follows a number.
reading_mnemonic:
This uses the kun'yomi reading of 毎, which you haven't learned yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

<vocabulary>For every</vocabulary> kanji you burn, you <reading>go to</reading> (ごと) Tokyo Disneyland as a reward. It's a bit of an expensive habit, but I think you deserve it.

examples.en: It's just a fluke.
examples.ja: ただのまぐれだよ。

examples.en: It was just a lucky guess.
examples.ja: まぐれで当たっただけなんだよね。

examples.en: Even if it's a fluke, it's still great!
examples.ja: まぐれでもすごいよ！

meaning_mnemonic:
Somebody tried to <reading>mug Re</reading>mi (まぐれ), your friend, but by <vocabulary>chance</vocabulary> they managed to escape! Their escape was a <vocabulary>fluke</vocabulary>, but what a relief they didn't get mugged.

This word can be written in kanji, but the kana version is way more common. In fact, it'd be quite a fluke if you saw it in kanji.

examples.en: Dad's an active professional wrestler.
examples.ja: お父さんは現役のプロレスラーです。

examples.en: The author of this manga is still a high school student.
examples.ja: このマンガの作者は、現役高校生なんです。

examples.en: I am thinking of going overseas for a year without enrolling in college straight out of high school.
examples.ja: 現役で大学に入学しないで、一年間海外に行こうと思うんです。

meaning_mnemonic:
At the <kanji>present time</kanji> you're providing a <kanji>service</kanji>, so you're <vocabulary>actively working</vocabulary>. 現役 means you have a certain role (such as school teacher or a high school student, etc.) and you're still <vocabulary>active</vocabulary> in that role, as opposed to being retired or having graduated.

This word is also often used to describe students who are taking or have passed a university entrance exam while they were still high school students.
reading_mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. You learned the readings for both of these, but 役 uses a less common reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you remember this:

You're <vocabulary>actively working</vocabulary> at the <reading>駅</reading> (えき) and you plan to remain <vocabulary>active</vocabulary> there forever! You sure do love that 駅, it's like you're inseparable.

examples.en: This is a stretching exercise that helps relieve stiff shoulders.
examples.ja: これは肩こりが楽になるストレッチです。

examples.en: There is a good massage technique to loosen stiff shoulders.
examples.ja: 肩こりをほぐす良いマッサージがあります。

examples.en: You're experiencing shoulder stiffness because you spend too much time playing smartphone games.
examples.ja: スマホゲームばっかりしてるから肩こりになるんだよ。

meaning_mnemonic:
When your shoulders get a little こり, it means you've got <vocabulary>shoulder stiffness</vocabulary> or a <vocabulary>stiff neck</vocabulary>. 

The こり here is a nominalized version of the verb こる, which means "to become stiff," so maybe that'll help you remember this!
reading_mnemonic: You already know the reading of 肩, and this is just that with some hiragana added on!

examples.en: Just be honest and admit it.
examples.ja: 素直に認めろよ。

examples.en: I'm glad I could hear your honest feelings.
examples.ja: 君の素直な気持ちが聞けてうれしいよ。

examples.en: It's important to have the openness to accept advice from others.
examples.ja: 人のアドバイスを素直に受け入れられる素直さって大事だよね。

meaning_mnemonic:
Remember how 直 can also mean "direct?" Well, if someone has an <kanji>element</kanji> of <kanji>direct</kanji>ness to them, they're probably a really <vocabulary>honest</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>upfront</vocabulary> person.

素直 usually describes someone who's sincere, emotionally open, willing to listen, and not stubborn. In some contexts, it can also imply someone is obedient or compliant. For example, a child who always does what they're told without objection might be called 素直.
reading_mnemonic:
The reading for this is a bit of a weird one. It uses on'yomi for 素, then it uses the kun'yomi for 直. You know both readings, but it's all a little strange, so here's a mnemonic help you:

If you're <vocabulary>honest</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>upfront</vocabulary> with yourself, you know it's time to <reading>sue now</reading> (すなお). What that person did to you… they definitely deserve be sued, now. Don't try to brush it off, don't let them silence you. Be <vocabulary>obedient</vocabulary> to your feelings and sue now!

examples.en: As expected, there are many older people here at this time of day, huh?
examples.ja: やっぱりこの時間は、年配の人が多いですね。

examples.en: This game can be enjoyed by both children and the elderly.
examples.ja: このゲームは、お子様からご年配の方まで楽しんでいただけます。

examples.en: There are only elderly people left in this village now.
examples.ja: この村にはもう年配者しか残っていないんですよ。

meaning_mnemonic:
As the <kanji>years</kanji> get <kanji>distribute</kanji>d, you slowly turn into an <vocabulary>elderly</vocabulary> <vocabulary>senior</vocabulary>, proud of your <vocabulary>old age</vocabulary>.

This word is used to politely describe an elderly person, as in 年配の方 or 年配者.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The はい goes to a ぱい, because… elderly persons love <reading>pie</reading> (ぱい), right?

examples.en: It's so sunny — almost like yesterday's typhoon didn't really happen.
examples.ja: 昨日の台風がウソの様に晴れてるね。

examples.en: Our Wi-Fi is as fast as light.
examples.ja: うちのWiFiは光の様に速い。

examples.en: He showed up for our first date riding a horse, as though he were a prince.
examples.ja: 彼は初めてのデートに王子の様に馬に乗って現れたの。

meaning_mnemonic: You learned 様 is a "formal name ender," but it can also mean <kanji>manner</kanji>. When you attach this to another noun with の and add に on the end to make it an adverb, you can describe something that's being done <vocabulary>similarly to</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>in the same way as</vocabulary> something else. In other words, something about it is just <vocabulary>like</vocabulary> that other thing — almost <vocabulary>as if</vocabulary> they were one and the same!
reading_mnemonic:
Even though this word isn't a compound, 様 actually uses the on'yomi here. Since you didn't learn the on'yomi with the kanji, here's a mnemonic to help you out:

Many foods are made <vocabulary>similarly to</vocabulary> <reading>yo</reading>gurt (よう): kefir, skyr, lassi… The list goes on. What's that? Those are just subcategories of yogurt, you say? No, no, no. They're made <vocabulary>in the same way as</vocabulary> yogurt and they taste a lot <vocabulary>like</vocabulary> yogurt, but they're not yogurt. Yogurt stands alone.
